utterances: I think Isabel Briggs Myers would also be quite disappointed.

And I think she would have felt quite sad by how, you know, people can just take knockoff versions of it online, how quizzes like Buzzfeed quizzes basically parody the logic of type by saying things like, you know, by asking you which Taylor Swift song reveals something about which ""Friends"" character you might be.
And I think she would be quite disappointed by how loosely and what an unregulated fashion the indicator was allowed to circulate.
And I also think she, you know, her primary objective was not to make money with it.

She wanted it to truly be useful to people, to help them figure out what it was that they should be doing in their lives because as a mother and a wife herself who often felt like her potential had been thwarted, that emerged to her as one of the most important questions that anybody could answer.
That's Merve Emre.
Her book is ""The Personality Brokers: The Strange History Of Myers-Briggs And The Birth Of Personality Testing.
Merve, thanks so much.
Thank you, Melissa.
From NPR News, this is DAY TO DAY.
Burger King is trying to separate itself from other companies in our fast-food nation.
The chain has decided to use suppliers that treat some of the animals on its menu more humanely.
Marketplace's Janet Babin is here.
And Janet, exactly what changes is Burger King making?
Well, Madeleine, the company confirms that it's going to start buying eggs and pig products from suppliers who don't cage the animals.
And when it can, it's going to use suppliers who slaughter chickens in a more humane way.
Now, it's going to start small, initially only a tiny percentage of eggs and pig meat products will come from these more humane suppliers.
But the company expects the numbers are going to grow over time as more suppliers use these methods.
Pig-meat products?
Pork.
Okay.
And to the rest of us.
Okay.
Well so these pigs and these chickens aren't exactly going to be scampering across, you know, clover fields, right?
I mean they'll still be in factory farms?
That is true.
But many people who are experts in this stuff say that these conditions are going to be much better.
I spoke with Paul Shapiro, he's with the Humane Society of the United States.
And he says the suppliers that Burger King's going to start to use have different living arrangements for their animals, and that lets them live more normal lives.

So these animals will now be able to walk around, they'll be able to socialize and engage in more of their natural behaviors than they otherwise would have, but that does not mean that they have an ideal life by any means.
Right now, sows are usually in crates that are really tiny and they're about two feet by seven feet and the pigs can't really turn around at all.
And the hens are in these wire cages - I don't know if you've seen them; they're called battery cages, and they don't really allow them to move around much either.

But the new suppliers put the pigs in like a group housing system, and the hens, too; they're more in a group setting, they're indoors but they are able to walk around and engage in more normal activities.
And socialize.
Well, will this put pressure on other restaurants, McDonalds for example, to make these changes?
Well, analyst Dennis Lombardi with WD Partners thinks yes, it will.
He says the changes for Burger King are more than just a publicity stunt in that customers are starting to ask for these ethical changes and the company's reacting to customers.
Consumers across the board are getting much more educated and much more aware and much more vocal about product and ingredients.
Between media and a more educated consumer, we're seeing this as an ongoing trend.

Now, a Burger King spokesman told me that the company made the changes based on the advice of its internal animal welfare board and because it was the right thing to do but not because of pressure from any outside groups or any customers at all.
And well, it won't have a specific marketing campaign about this, Madeleine.
It does say if it has a positive effect on customers, all the better.
All right.
Well, thank you, Janet.
Janet Babin of Public Radio's daily business show, MARKETPLACE, produced by American Public Media.
(Soundbite of music)

You know, it isn't just for mortgages, you've got credit cards and car loans even payday lending.
That story and the rest of the day's business news, it's from American Public Media.

DAY TO DAY returns in a moment.
Joining us now is Flora Lichtman, our video producer, soon-to-be video editor.
Hi, Ira.
Thanks.
You're welcome.
What have we got today for our Video Pick of the Week?
We want to take a few minutes now to try to understand the strange story of an American who has risen to the upper ranks of ISIS.
His name is Zulfi Hoxha.
He's Albanian-American, the son of a pizza shop owner in New Jersey.
And his case may tell us a good deal about how jihadist recruitment networks work here in the U.S.
Seamus Hughes helps run the Program on Extremism at George Washington University, and he has co-authored a story on Hoxha for The Atlantic.
Seamus Hughes, welcome.
Thanks for having me.
Sketch out for us his basic biome.
What do we know about him?
Yesterday actually was his birthday.
He turned 26.
He traveled to Syria in April 2015.
Once he got to Turkey, four days later, he joined an ISIS training camp.
And he was able to do that by connecting with another Westerner, a guy named Junaid Hussain, who's a well-known ISIS propagandist, who was able to help him cross the border.
Six months later, he's in an ISIS video.
And that video shows what appears to be Hoxha beheading Kurdish soldiers.
If that is in fact him, this would be the first American shown...
Yeah.
...Carrying out a beheading in an ISIS propaganda video.
And you know, it's always impossible to pinpoint what's going on in somebody's head, what the exact trigger was for him of what attracted him to ISIS.
But what do we know about how he was radicalized?
We know he was very active online.
We have court records and transcripts of him trading ISIS videos back and forth with two or three other Americans.
And so you clearly saw an individual who was part of an online network and used that online network to facilitate his offline travel.
Talk to me about what his case may illustrate about how Americans living here in America are being radicalized today.
In the U.S.
context, you're not talking about very large numbers.
So we've had about 150 people arrested for terrorism-related activities in the last three years.
But the guys that successfully got to Syria and Iraq - we're talking about dozens as opposed to kind of our European countries, which have hundreds of individuals that are traveling.
A much bigger pipeline.

A much bigger pipeline, and that's a reflection of a very aggressive law enforcement approach and also the fact that, you know, in general we don't have large populations of individuals that are drawn to this ideology.
When you say an aggressive law enforcement approach, you mean maybe more would be attracted to this, but there is something the U.S.
government is doing to step in and shut it down.
Yeah.
The federal government and the FBI in particular shuts down networks before they form.
You know, if you're in the U.K., you see these clusters of folks.
In the U.S., you're talking about ones and twos of individuals that are drawn to the ideology.
There's a use of informants.
There's a use of FISA.
There's a whole...
FISA - the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act.
Exactly - so the ability of the tools that we have in the U.S.
that European or other Western countries do not have.
What might his story tell us about the way that the ISIS threat is evolving?
The Islamic State doesn't have much of a state anymore left in Iraq and Syria.
Do we still see people like Hoxha wanting to actually go there - not just being attracted to ISIS online but wanting to pick up and travel?
Well, we've seen essentially a twofold thing happening.
One is ISIS telling these individuals, do not come to Syria and Iraq anymore.
Move on to other conflicts, or do what you can where you are.
And so the FBI director's described it as essentially going down to a trickle - one and two individuals arrested every month, not like the numbers we saw in 2015 when Hoxha traveled.
So how big a threat is someone like Hoxha or other Americans who are rising through ISIS ranks?
How big a threat they pose to U.S.
national security?
What we've seen in past jihadist conflicts is that these individuals that spend time in Syria and Iraq essentially act as nodes for the next generation or the next conflict, right?
They have the connections.
They connect Americans or other Westerners with people that they know and get other people over to next conflicts.
We saw this with Anwar al-Awlaki with al-Qaida with, you know, how powerful it was as a recruiting tool for them to have somebody fluent in English apparently.
